case_vignette: A 24-year-old obese woman presents to the dermatology clinic with darkening, rough skin around the neck for six months. The rash is not painful or itchy. She has tried to clean the area with over the counter shampoo and rubbing alcohol without improvement. She denies any rash elsewhere on the body. The rash always begins as dark patches, and she denies any blistering or redness before the dark spots develop.   Physical examination reveals thick, velvety ropey hyperpigmented rough, poorly demarcated plaques circumferentially around the neck.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have dark, rough skin around my neck that has been there for six months.
Is this skin change accompanied by itching or pain?
No, it's not painful or itchy.
What is your age and sex?
I am a 24-year-old woman.
Have you used any new skin care products or spent more time in the sun recently?
No, I haven't used any new skin care products or spent more time in the sun recently.
Is there a family history of similar skin changes?
I don't have any family history of similar skin changes.
Final Diagnosis: Acanthosis Nigricans.
